title: The causal relevance of body mass index in different histological types of lung cancer: A Mendelian randomization study
author: Carreras-Torres
author_address: Section of Genetics, International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), Lyon, France
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on cancer
rationale: Body mass index (BMI) is inversely associated with lung cancer risk in observational studies, even though it increases the risk of several other cancers, which could indicate confounding by tobacco smoking or reverse causality.
outcome_study: Wang 2014 Lung cancer, ever smokers European both
exposure_independence: Auhors state GWAS independence threshold. Do not do formal test.
exposure_pleiotropy: BMI GRS was not associated with available measures of tobacco exposure in individual level data
power_calculation_how: power calculations for the MR analysis were performed acording to Burgess20, assuming a nominal statistical significance of alpha 0.05 and a genetic instrument explaining 2.7% of phenotype variance. 80% to detect OR of 1.21 for overall lung cancer, 1.32 for adenocarcinoma, 1.36 for squamous cell car- cinoma, 1.85 for small cell carcinoma, 1.36 for lung cancer overall ever smokers, and 2.14 for lung cancer overall never smokers
IV_strength: BMI GRS associated with BMI in individual level data of the study and was not associated with available measures of tobacco exposure.
limitations_overall: Little discussion of limitations of MR, especialy given small sample sizes.
limitations_pleiotropy: Used multiple SNPs so less likely to be biased by pleiotropy. No evidence of pleiotropic effects on estimates.

title: Obesity, metabolic factors and risk of different histological types of lung cancer: A Mendelian randomization study
author: Carreras-Torres
author_address: Section of Genetics, International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), Lyon, France
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on cancer
rationale: Assessing the relationship between lung cancer and metabolic conditions is challenging because of the confounding effect of tobacco. Mendelian randomization (MR), or the use of genetic instrumental variables to assess causality, may help to identify the metabolic drivers of lung cancer
outcome_study: McKay 2017 Lung cancer, ever smokers European both
exposure_independence: Auhors state GWAS independence threshold. Do not do formal test.
exposure_pleiotropy: Using MR-Base, we also evaluated the association between cigarette smoking for each genetic instrument associated with lung cancer risk, including BMI, LDL, and fasting insulin. Each SD increase in BMI increased cigarette consumption by 1.27 cigarettes (95%CI = 0.46:2.07; P = 2.1x10-3; MR likelihood based approach)
power_calculation_how: Power calculations on MR analyses were performed according to Burgess
limitations_overall: Association between BMI and lung cancer may be a result of an association between BMI and cigarette smoking.
limitations_pleiotropy: Said no limitations because used MR Egger and tested for BMI association with smoking
